summary: This is a transcript of a telephone conference before Magistrate Judge Debra C. Freeman in the case Doe v. Indyke et al. The conference addresses discovery disputes, the plaintiff's potential participation in the Epstein Victims Compensation Program, and scheduling issues. The plaintiff is a pseudonymous victim (Jane Doe) who was witness/victim No. 1 in the criminal indictment against Jeffrey Epstein. The discussion centers on whether to stay discovery given the compensation program, the scope of document production and depositions, and the efficient management of the case.

persons.name: Debra C. Freeman
persons.role: United States District Court Magistrate Judge
persons.context: Presiding over the telephone conference, managing discovery disputes and discussing case management in relation to the Epstein Victims Compensation Program.

persons.name: Roberta A. Kaplan
persons.context: Lead counsel for plaintiff Jane Doe, arguing against a stay of discovery, discussing the compensation program, and advocating for her client's right to proceed with litigation.

persons.name: Bennet J. Moskowitz
persons.role: Attorney for Defendants (Co-executors of Epstein estate)
persons.context: Lead counsel for the defendants (co-executors), arguing for a stay or slowdown of discovery to conserve estate resources and promote resolution through the compensation program.

persons.name: Kate L. Doniger
persons.context: Colleague of Roberta Kaplan on the call, providing details about medical records and document production.

persons.name: Molly S. DiRago
persons.context: Colleague of Bennet Moskowitz on the call, mentioned as being present.

persons.name: Jane Doe
persons.context: Pseudonymous plaintiff, identified as witness/victim No. 1 in the criminal indictment against Jeffrey Epstein. She was allegedly abused at age 14 and is considering the compensation program while litigating.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier whose estate is the defendant. The plaintiff alleges he raped her when she was a 14-year-old 'street kid'.

persons.name: Ken Feinberg
persons.context: Referenced as the preeminent designer of the Epstein Victims Compensation Program, though Jordana Feldman is the independent administrator.

persons.name: Jordana Feldman
persons.context: The independent administrator of the Epstein Victims Compensation Program who makes final determinations on claim awards.

persons.name: Don Hughes
persons.context: An 'illustrious expert' retained by plaintiff to testify on damages, specifically pain and suffering and future mental health costs.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned in passing as someone other cases allege a wider conspiracy regarding, but this plaintiff's case does not.

persons.name: Carole Ludwig
persons.context: Certified the transcript as a true and accurate record.

connections.description: Plaintiff alleges Jeffrey Epstein raped her when she was a 14-year-old homeless 'street kid'.
Kaplan is lead counsel representing the pseudonymous plaintiff Jane Doe in her civil suit against Epstein's estate.
Moskowitz represents the defendant co-executors of Jeffrey Epstein's estate.
Feinberg designed the compensation program; Feldman is the independent administrator who makes award determinations.
Dr. Don Hughes is the damages expert retained by plaintiff's counsel to testify on her pain, suffering, and future mental health costs.
Opposing counsel in the litigation, engaging in discovery disputes and differing on case management strategy regarding the compensation program.

events.title: Telephone Conference on Discovery and Compensation Program
events.description: Magistrate Judge Debra C. Freeman holds a conference to address discovery disputes, the plaintiff's consideration of the Epstein Victims Compensation Program, and scheduling. The judge urges cost-efficient litigation and cooperation.

events.title: Establishment of Epstein Victims Compensation Program
events.description: Reference to the recently established compensation program for Epstein's victims, administered by Jordana Feldman and designed by Ken Feinberg. Most other plaintiffs have stayed their cases to participate.

events.title: Alleged Abuse of Jane Doe
events.description: The underlying event: Plaintiff Jane Doe alleges she was raped by Jeffrey Epstein when she was a 14-year-old homeless 'street kid'. She was witness/victim No. 1 in the criminal indictment.

locations: Southern District of New York (court jurisdiction)
350 Fifth Avenue, Suite 7110, New York, NY (Kaplan Hecker & Fink LLP address)
875 Third Avenue, New York, NY (Troutman Sanders LLP address)
227 W. Monroe Street, Suite 3900, Chicago, IL (Troutman Sanders address)
keyFacts: The plaintiff, Jane Doe, is the pseudonymous 'victim No. 1' from the criminal indictment against Jeffrey Epstein and alleges he raped her when she was 14.

The plaintiff is considering participating in the Epstein Victims Compensation Program but is continuing to litigate because she believes a trial could yield a higher award than the program might offer.
Discovery disputes include the adequacy of plaintiff's Rule 26(a) damages computation, production of medical records (especially mental health), and communications with the press and other counsel.

The estate's counsel argues that aggressive litigation depletes resources that could otherwise go to victims via the compensation program, while plaintiff's counsel argues the program does not guarantee all estate funds go to victims.
Judge Freeman emphasizes the Federal Rules' goals of a 'just, speedy, and inexpensive' determination and urges both sides to litigate cooperatively and cost-consciously.
